awd_titl_txt: ISS:   Constrained Vapor Bubbles of Ideal Mixtures
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1637816
PI: Plawsky, Joel L.

Heat pipes are heat transfer devices that are used regularly for cooling a variety of electronic equipment, including laptop computers.  Heat pipes use a fluid to transfer heat, but an essential feature of the device is that the fluid undergoes change of phase between liquid and vapor.  The detailed motion of the liquid and vapor, and the motion and dynamics of the interface between the two phases, can strongly affect the performance of heat pipes and similar systems.  Recent results suggest that the use of a fluid mixture, instead of a pure fluid, can help overcome limitations on performance and unanticipated failures of multiphase heat transfer systems.  This project will use the constrained vapor bubble system on board the International Space Station (ISS) to examine various interfacial phenomena for mixtures of organic fluids.  Parallel experiments conducted on Earth will help reveal the influence of gravity on interfacial dynamics and heat transfer performance characteristics.  Results from the project will provide information that practitioners can use to improve phase-change heat and mass transfer operations, which are becoming increasingly important in fields such as energy conversion, distillation, microelectronics cooling, coating processes, and space exploration.   The project will also provide opportunities for students to participate in research through Rensselaer's Undergraduate Research Program.
 
This project will investigate interfacial phenomena and thermal-fluid performance for pentane/isohexane fluid mixtures in a wickless heat pipe.  Parallel experiments on Earth and on the ISS will address fundamental issues, including the effects of Marangoni forces on fluid motion and device performance.  Condensation and the presence of Leidenfrost droplets at the hot ends of the device are of particular interest.  The project will examine mixtures near 50:50 composition for which ground-based experiments have shown deviations from ideal mixture behavior.  These deviations will be magnified in microgravity and will alter interfacial characteristics and heat transfer performance of the wickless heat pipe.  The experiments will map the vapor-liquid interface using multi-wavelength interferometry.  This technique can isolate curvature gradients that drive fluid flow and can determine whether a phase change is occurring locally within the liquid menisci present throughout the device.  Particular focus will be given to regions near the heated end of the device where the competition between Marangoni and capillary forces can lead to a new limitation on performance and where disjoining pressure/intermolecular force effects appear to promote unexpected condensation.  The interface mapping will be combined with temperature profile measurements to understand, and ultimately predict, the thermal performance of these devices.  Using stopped motion and video applications of the interferometry technique, the stability of the liquid menisci and how stability depends upon heat input and liquid composition will be explored.  Thermal-fluid models will be developed to help explain the observations both at the meniscus and the device levels.  Results of the project will lead to the design of better thermal management devices that rely on phase change heat transfer and will help outline the limits of evaporation and condensation processes, the stability of liquid menisci, and the applicability of the ideal fluid mixture approximation, one of the cornerstones of phase equilibrium thermodynamics.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Heat pipes are used in satellites, space vehicles and laptop computers to keep their electronics cool.  They operate with no moving parts and just require a heat source and a heat sink.  They operate by evaporating a working fluid at the hot end, condesing the vapor at the cold end, and returning the condesed liquid back to the hot end.  Most requie wicks.  Few have been fully commercialized using liquid mixtures because their reliability and performance are more difficult to predict.  A transparent, wickless, heat pipe containing a 50:50 mixture of of the small hydrocarbons pentane and 2-methypentane was run on the International Space Station (ISS) to investigate how the liquid-vapor interface behaves when a perfectly miscible fluid mixture is used. As the heater temperature exceeded a threshold of about 45 ˚C and the temperature difference between the heater and condenser exceeded 50 ˚C, spontaneous, single-frequency (coherent), oscillations in temperature, pressure, and film thickness appeared along the axis connecting the heater and condenser.   The system was not designed to be a a form of pulsating heat pipe since the volume of liquid contained in the device was only 10% of that in normal pulsating heat pipes.  Oscillations were not observed in ground-based experiments nor when a 94:6 pentane/2-methylpentane liquid mixture was previously operated on the ISS.  Oscillations arose due to evaporative distillation that partially separates the two liquids at the heater end and enriches that end with 2-methylpentane, and an entropy driven recombination of the liquids at the condenser end sincce the two liquids do not want to remain separated. The oscillation period was slow, ~16 - 25 s, and could be adjusted within that time range depending on the heater temperature and the temperature difference between heater and condenser.  The mixture outperformed a pure pentane system leading to a 47% overall improvement in heat rejection and double the heat removal rate right at the heater wall.  We termed the phenomenon FASER, flow amplification by sustained entropic reinforcement, based on the “purity” of the oscillations.

Broader Impacts

           There are three unusual aspects to the results that point to broader impacts at least intellectually.  The first is the purity and linewidth of the oscillation frequency.  Signal-to-noise ratios were on the order of 200:1 and linewidths of the frequency were on the order of 1%.  The linewidth in particular, rivals or beats commercial diode laser performance and the frequency is so stable one could use the system as a kind of clock.  The second is the precise turn-on and turn-off temperatures characteristic of the phenomenon.  Within a few tenths of a degree, the oscillations start and as the temperature is raised beyond a threshold, the oscillations quickly cease.  The former is also a hallmark of a laser cavity oscillator and our system is also a cavity with the heater wall at one end and a pressure transducer at the other end.  The vapor is akin to the laser's excited state while the liquid can be viewed as the ground state.  The third aspect is the mystery of how such a complex and messy system involving all three modes of heat transfer (conduction, convection, and radiation), evaporation, condensation, diffusive and convective mass transfer, capillary flow, fluid friction, mxing, and distillation all combine to form a coherent oscillator whose response can be altered by changing the temperature difference between the hot and cold ends.  The energy to drrive the liquid separation comes from the heat input while the restoring energy to remix the fluids is closely related to how a diffusion refrigerator works in say, a quantum computer.

Additional ISS experiments will be required to more fully appreciate the behavior and most importantly, to determine the range of conditions that can be accessed by changing composition and by changing the properties of the fluids involved.  Lastly, the work has practical implications for the cooling of microelectronics in space probes and on Earth if we can come up with a configuration that reproduces the oscillation effect in 1-g.

The project contributed to the education of two PhD students,  and undergraduate students from the chemical, mechanical,  and nuclear engineering departments.  It also resulted in over 5 presentations and 6 publications with many more in the works as we continue to analyze data.
